113.content:
"I don't care what power you give me, I just want an escape from my life." you say, seating in the Power Broker's desk.

"Well that's a simple enough matter. However, I can't guarantee you'll like the the life I give you," the Broker replies. He rummages through his files, eventually passing a thick folder across the desk. "I think you might like this one. Comes with a whole list of powers, a costume, a superhero lair and a job to boot."

Flipping the folder open, you're excited at the array of abilities this one power grants you. Immortality. The ability to slow down time to an imperceptible crawl. Innate magical abilities. Can open any locked door and shrink and stretch the body to fit down any sized hole. Enhanced digestive system able to process vast quantities of alcohol and... mince pies in one sitting.

You flip a page. Underneath the word 'Lair' is a picture of a large log cabin festooned with red and green decorations, located in what appears to be Alaska.

On the next page, titled 'love interest' is a picture of a grandmotherly old woman with rosy cheeks and silver hair tied up with a bow, who looks chubby enough to give wonderful hugs.

"Interested?" the Broker asks.

"You want to give me... Santa's powers?!"

"Not just his powers, his whole life, everything! He gave it all up. Said the pressure was getting to him. Pressure, hah! The man works one day a year. So what do you say? Do it for the kids. It'll be a grim, dark Christmas if you don't."

1133.content:
"Uhhhhh..." You say, voice croaking at a high octave as you stare at the Power Broker. You look back at the folder, the picture of Mrs. Claus on full display as she flashes a rosy smile towards the camera. "I don't know..."

"Come on, you'll enjoy it! You get to spend months wolfing down the delicious cooking of your new wife, and trust me, it's delicious, you get to hang around the house all day doing nothing, and you also get thousands of minions to command! All fun, all games, no work. Come on, boy, I've been sitting on this for years already. Kids aren't getting their presents."

You once again wrinkle your nose as you take another look at the manila folder sprawled out on the table. This could be you. This could be your life. But it's not you.

"Um... could I have something else?" You look upwards, seeing the content smirk on the Broker's face quickly vanish, soon replaced by a sharp grimace. If only looks could kill. "It's just... this is not me. This is not who I am. I don't just want to take the place of some old man. I want to be me."

"I can't believe this!" The Power Broker exclaims, throwing his hands up in mock surprise, as the candlelights on his desk flicker, causing the shadows of his fingers to dance rapidly and wildly. "First they tell you that they are not satisfied with their life. That they want to start anew. Then when you actually offer them something, they throw it back at you! All needy and picky. Selfish, all of them!"

You can only uncomfortably shift from one leg to the other as you awkwardly squirm in the chair, dodging the disappointed gaze that the Broker is throwing at you. This is even worse than dealing with your mother.

"Er.... um... sorry?" is the only thing that you can mutter in response as your eyes shift downwards in shame. Perhaps this was a bad idea after all.

A lingering silence fills the air as you examine the floor, the lacquer paint more thick on several wooden panels than on the others. You finally grow restless, raising your head to see the still and stiff Broker sitting in his chair, jaw agape. He slowly closes it.

"What did you just say to me, boy?" He growls in a low tone, gaze piercing right through you as if you were transparent. You flinch. Did you somehow upset him one way or another?

"Er... sorry?" You repeat, backing away into your seat as your body forms a contour in the leather, the elasticity giving in to your weight.

"Can you repeat it to me?" His voice is now softer, almost like a whisper.

"Sure. Sorry." Your voice is now firm, without hesitation, as you repeat the word for the third time. You aren't quite sure why the aged man is so interested in this, but you sure as hell aren't going to let this chance go.

"Sorry. Sorry. Sorry." The Broker mutters, repeating the word ad nauseam. It was as if though he was bewitched by the word, carelessly chasing it along a narrow path as it enticed further and further into itself. His repetitions last an entire minute before he snaps out of the spell, and upon realizing the smoke of the burnt out candles wafting at him, he quickly snaps his fingers as the wax seems to rebuild and light itself anew. Almost as if though it traveled back in time.

"Sorry. Now that's a word I haven't heard in ye-... no, decades. People always come to me, demanding powers as they incessantly bargain for more and more power. Yet do they ever thank me? No! All they ever say is 'me, me, me'. Yet what about myself? Listen kid, I like you. What is it that you're actually looking for?"

You scratch the back of your hair as you thoughts float through your brain, your nails rustling through the stubs of your growing hair.

"I don't really know." You finally admit, shrugging your shoulders. "At first I just thought that I wanted to be someone different. You know, to get rid of this life. But now that I think about it, I kind of want to change myself instead. To... improve myself? A better me, I guess."

The Broker nods his head in a short manner.

"Understandable. Humans always desire the sense of accomplishment, even if it dwells deep within themselves. Unfortunately, I cannot create such powers. I am a Giver, someone who trades. I simply cannot fulfill that wish."

Catching your dismayed look, he quickly interjects.

"But! What I can do is give you something. Not a power, but an item. Even though it is imbued with the essence of others, it's raw. Completely unnurtured. You can take it and make it your own. Become a new hero. It's possible, though it might take a milennia... or a couple thousand. What do you say, kid?"

Your eyes gleam. You get to become your own superhero? To leave your name in myths and legends? To maybe even fight against other superheroes and gods themselves? You definitely don't want to miss that opportunity as you quickly bob your head in an approving gesture.

"Great! I have a couple of items left over. What do you say about... oh, this one will be perfect for you! It is..."

114.content:
The Broker isn't quite how you'd expected him. The man Nathan had described had been calm, collected, professional. This man is anything but. His eyes have a wild, sleep-deprived look, there is sweat on his suit, and he keeps tugging at his tie as if struggling to breathe, even though it hangs like a loose noose around his shoulders.

The office is a scene of chaos. People scurry back and forth. Curiously, most of them seem to be the same person.

"Techno, erase everything on those hard drives," the Broker snaps at one of the underlings who moves quickly to the nearest computer, reaching into the long cloak that shrouds his body and drawing out a long, fleshy cable from the base of his neck. His body stiffens as he slides it into the computer port. "Electro, fry everything the second those hard drives are wiped." Electro, a woman wearing nothing but dense bright-yellow fur, grins, and the room instantly comes alive with static charges. "Folk?"

"Sir," half the room says in unison, the duplicates snapping to attention.

He points at four with rifles slung over their backs . "You, you, you, and you, get up on the roof. Anything that isn't a bird or a plane, shoot it down."

"Yes, sir!"

He watches them leave then turns suddenly, almost falling over you in the process. "Why are you still here?" he scowls. His hand slips into his jacket. "Who sent you?!"

"Nathan did, uh, sir."

There's the distinct click off a pistol being cocked. "Just torched my records so you're going to have to be a little more specific than that, kid."

"Nathan Huggins! He told me where to find you. He said you gave him luck."

The Broker seems to relax a little. He removes his hand slowly. "Right. The probability manipulation. I remember him." Suddenly he grins. "Looks like some of that luck rubbed off on you, kid. You got here at just the right time. How would you like some big powers, real Earth shakers. Totally free of charge."

"What's the catch?"

"Why should there be a catch? Look the truth is I overcharged your friend for what is, between you and me, a pretty weak power. I feel bad. Let me make it up."

A man with a face like clay steps into the room. "We go now," he growls.

The Broker holds out his hand. "You've got about thirty seconds to choose. After that I'm gone for good."

"Okay, I'll take it!" you say hurriedly.

He gives you...

1142.content:
A single touch is all it takes. You feel the energy surge into your body, buzzing and sparking in your gut and the tips of your fingers, making you light headed. A rush of elation fills your head. You can achieve anything. Anything at all. All you have to do is wish it.

A massive thud like a bomb going off brings you lurching back to reality. Lumps of the ceiling crash down around you and dust fills the air. The building is shaken violently as something impacts against the outside again and again. It sounds like the place is being shelled.

The clay-faced man grabs the Broker by the arm. "We go now!" He resists, pushing the other man away, drawing the pistol from within his jacket.

An alien language booms through the air. "What's happening? What the hell is that!" you scream.

"Those things are the Monitors of reality," the Broker bellows back. "They're like multiverse police. They seek out and destroy threats to reality." He levels the gun at your head. "People like you."

"What! But I'm not - " Realization dawns. "You bastard! Whatever you gave me, take it back!"

The ceiling is ripped away and you stare up at a sky filled with vast, inhuman entities.

"Run far enough and you might lose them. Good luck," the Broker yells, squeezing the trigger.
-------
The noise ceases immediately. With your eyes squeezed tight shut, it is a long time before you realise you're not actually dead. Slowly you open one eye.

You're standing in the Broker's office. It is peaceful, serene, quiet except for the sound of a car passing outside. The ceiling is intact. The stacks of fried computers and torched paperwork are gone. The paintings on the walls aren't even crooked.

Time travel? you wonder. Then again, he had mentioned something about your powers being reality-based. Perhaps you've jumped to a reality where the Monitors couldn't find you.

You don't even try to run. And it wasn't because your legs were chained to the floor out of fear of the gargantuan mass of muscle hurling towards you, but because you frankly don't even care. You have been imbued with the power to travel through time, twist dimensions, and warp the fabric of reality itself. Why should you even be afraid of some physical muscle?

The doll was missing its limbs, only its body and torso were present, having been left with an open hole only at the mouth end. He thrusts a glass that is filled to the brim with a noxious smelling brown liquid, alcohol practically evaporating right before your very eyes. "Don't worry, it's not poisonous. Just a little oversaturated."

You are pleasantly surprised that not only does it go down well in this dreary atmosphere, but the taste is quite refined as well. It doesn't even give you the shivers. Magic, you think.

"Oh... oh fuck. I get it now. You probably got them from an alternate self of mine. And since I don't throw around these big powers willy nilly, you most likely served as a distraction to run away. What a cruel man," he sighs, gazing at you, the irony lost on him. "Anyway..."

It wasn't an idea so much as a realisation. Life had been on a downward trajectory even before the divorce. Now it was in free fall. Your performance at work had been in the dirt ever since she'd walked out on you - commissions had dried up and management were already making moves to fire you. Even this shitty flat, with its peeling, mould-encrusted walls, was more than you could afford. What little money Cassandra had left you with had been spent. In a month, you'll be out on your ass.

With a weary yet resolute sigh, you switched off the "documentary" and drained your beer. Until the time that you were super successful bikini model Kate Upton, sacrifices would have to be made. Sacrifices such as your son. How biblical.

Perhaps it would do him some good, kicking him out. Since the divorce he had done nothing but seclude himself in his room, appearing every so often only to eat your food and act like a hormonal, horny teenager. He had no job, no girlfriend, no drive. You loved him dearly, but making him land on his feet and fend for himself was in his best interests.

You pressed your ear against his bedroom door for signs of life. His music player was blasting out something godawful. You knocked loudly and gave him time to zip up his pants.

Nothing... You hammered harder. "Chris, open up, it's your father." No reply. "Chris, open the door, I want to have a talk." ..... "Fine. I'm coming in."

His room, when you stepped into it, was freezing. The window was wide open, curtains billowing in the cold wind. A stack of comic books had been swept off his desk and strewn about the room, pages flapping. His PC was lit up and playing its noise-music to an empty room.

Huh. You suppressed a smile at the idea that the little bastard had been sneaking out behind your back. Perhapss he wasn't as antisocial as you thought. "Just wish you could do it without wasting the heating and electric," you muttered, pulling closed the window and powering down the computer. As it shuts down, you catch sight of a text document and the words, 'Power Broker 117 graymalkin road dont forget!!!!'. With a last disapproving glance at his shelves of comics, you stepped outside.

Graymalkin road? you thought, returning to the living room. That's a rough part of town. What business could he possibly have there? God, please don't let it be drugs.

Kate Upton: A Beautiful Life was no longer running when you flicked the TV back on. Breaking news was plastered across the lower half of the screen and a newswoman stood against the famial backdrop of the city high-street. The red-blue lights of police cars illuminated the area.

"I'm standing live at the scene of where chaos broke out earlier when a mysterious individual attempted to steal millions of pounds from a high security vault in the bank behind me," the newswoman said. "Police are asking for witnesses and for anybody who can help them make sense of the following footage."

The screen shifted to grainy CCTV footage of the heist. It showed...
1213.title: Confront your son

12131.content:
The screen shifted to grainy CCTV footage of the inside of the bank. A squad of armed police crouched behind several overturned desks, their rifles trained on the massive circular door of the bank vault. The footage played on, though nothing seemed to be happening.

"Notice anything strange?" the newswoman said, as the footage began to loop. "Watch again. This time keep your eyes on the bottom left corner." Curious you shifted forward but even still you could see nothing. "Still not seen it? How about now?" the newswoman said smugly. The footage played a third time except with a red circle over the image which highlighted a black smudge, barely more than a few pixels high, moving across the floor of the bank from the vault, making a beeline for the doorway. It slipped between the feet of one of the cops.

You sat back disappointing. So the bank has a rat problem. Hardly newsworthy.

"If you had trouble spotting it in that last clip, perhaps this next video will be easier," the voiceover said with an air of relish as the view switched. Now they were high above the bank in a helicopter, looking down at the police cars clustered around the steps. You shook your head and cracked open another beer as the video played.

Suddenly one of the cops crouched behind the car lurched to his feet, wildly pointing his pistol at the floor and rapidly emptying his clip into the tarmac. The scene became chaos as the police dove for cover.

There was something on the ground, near to where the cop had fired, hard to see at first but becoming clearer. A black dot on the image. It was growing. Now it was the size of an animal, perhaps a dog. Then it was as big as a child. It was a person, arms and legs pumping as it ran, gathering speed. It barreled into the policeman, knocking him off his feet. The others had seen it now and had leveled their guns on it, but didn't seem to be shooting. Perhaps they thought it was a child.

Except now it was the size of a man. Then two men. A cop car crunched as the expanding figure clambered over it. It was trying to escape. The camera desperately zoomed out to keep the entirety of the figure in shot, which was now rubbing shoulders with the three story buildings that lined the street. The giant was tearing down the street, cars crumpling beneath its feet as it ran, heading straight for the camera, and the footage cut out as the helicopter veered to the side to escape its path.

The news reporter was using her quiet voice reserved for serious occasions. "News Central would like to remind viewers that what they just saw was real, unedited footage from the scene of the bank raid earlier today. Once again, if you know anything that may help the authorities make sense of these shocking images, please call the number on your screen now." Attempts by the police to identify the figure - believed to be male and in his early twenties - have been hampered by the mask obscuring both his eyes and part of his nose."

A freeze frame of the person came on the screen. The beer slipped from your fingers. It was impossible to tell for sure, what with the mask covering his eyes and part of his nose, but you'd recognise that t-shirt anywhere... It was your son!

"At least its not drugs..."

That's when you heard the sound of the cat flap. Weird, because you didn't even have a cat. Tiny footfalls pass outside the living room door. Your son's bedroom door creaks.

1551.content:
The Power Broker
Appears to be a man in his early thirties with short, neat hair dressed in a simple grey suit. Seems to care only for making money through buying and selling abilities from super powered individuals. He is almost totally amoral, willing to bestow anybody with any power as long as they have the money.
Stores abilities in his body through touch but cannot use them himself. He is only able to grant abilities that he currently has in stock, so to speak - that is, powers that he has drained from other empowered individuals. As such, he usually asks why his client wants an ability and then grants one from what is available according to what will satisfy their needs.

For protection he has a team of empowered individuals that are faithful to him. They will track down and kill anybody that crosses him.

The goons

"Hardcore"
Powers - durability/shapeshifting
Hardcore is a dour man of late middle-age with a sagging, jowly face; brown skin; and a thick Eastern European accent. On closer inspection, his flesh is revealed to be something resembling soft clay, which can be manipulated into a variety of different forms.
His inorganic body is resilient to most damage. Bullets will barely make him flinch Dismemberment will only serve to anger him. The only way to stop him permanently is to expose and destroy the solid stone core hidden within his body.
His malleable flesh allows him to mimic the appearance of others. He is no great actor however. Whatever his form, his strong accent easily gives him away.

"Trance"
Powers - hypnosis/telekinesis
Trance is a 30ish Englishman with rather striking eyes that shift through a variety of neon hues. His gaze is hypnotic - anybody that meets it becomes a puppet under his control. He has a manipulative, somewhat sadistic personality to match his abilities, but is notable afraid of his employer.
Has a limited telekinesis capable of flinging away objects in his close vicinity.

"Folk"
Powers - self-duplication
Folk is a young, athletic woman capable of spawning physical copies of herself. These duplicates possess her memories and skills, and are capable of acting independently. While lacking in powers and individually quite weak they are a handy source of disposable soldiers for the Broker, able to overcome even the strongest empowered individuals through swamping them with sheer numbers.
Upon death, the clones melt away into pink goop.

"Funk"
Powers - mood and mind-altering pheromones
Funk works for the Broker only on the promise that he will eventually receive a better power. He has the ability to emit (through unsavoury means) an assortment of gases and fumes from his body that effect those that breath them in a variety of ways, ranging from depression to arousal, aggression, forgetfulness, or confusion. He can also expell a cloud of dense black smoke to escape dangerous situations.
Has few friends even among his team.

The technology wielded by ROBUST has advanced dramatically since they started operating in the field, and several generations of tech are in use - from the early, crudely mechanical prosthetics to the newer, sleeker designs, including infiltration models designed to pass off as human.

1553322.content:
MS. BROTHEL: (or even just Brothel)

Orwell Williams was just your regular, everyday familyman that worked tirelessly to provide for the people he loved. But once he found out that his ‘dedicated’ wife was sleeping out with his younger brother, his walls began to crash down. Following a heated divorce and a biased custody agreement for their children, Orwell tried seeking a way to fill the void that his wife had left in his life.

He turned to drugs, sex and crime to satiate his needs but it still wasn’t enough. He was a smart man and began to offer his intelligence to whatever organised crime syndicates could pay enough to support his new lifestyle. This however was still not enough money to keep him afloat and he began racking up huge debts to his former employers. The most notable of these was The Power Broker. The Broker sensed this is an opportunity to help himself out and agreed to annul Orwell’s debts on the condition that he dedicated his life to running The Broker’s prostitution rings.

Orwell readily agreed and (after transforming into an irresistible succubus) cleaned himself up and transformed The Broker’s Brothels into a booming business. The Broker bestowed upon him (her) the power of reality manipulation, allowing Brothel to alter anyone or anything that enters the brothel to her personal whim. These powers allow her to alter the physical compositions of the mental dispositions of whoever she wants, making her nigh omnipotent in her element. She also possesses shapeshifting and seduction powers, making herself irresistible to whomever she chooses and bending them to her will. Her seduction powers allow her to control the libidos of others, making her a very successful brothel owner indeed.

Although her reality manipulation powers put her on par with The Power Broker theoretically, the deal that they agreed restricts Brothel’s powers: although she’s a very powerful person, she is not as strong out of her element and her powers of reality manipulation are severely diminished. That being said, her powers of seduction could mean she could create a loyal army of people to follow and support her in and around communities so she could still retain her metaphorical ‘power’ even without the wider skill of reality manipulation.

(Note: sorry that this is so long. Don’t even know if anyone’s going to use it but I got really into the origin whilst I was writing and didn’t seem to be able to stop 😅. Anyways, hope you enjoyed this little character intro)

info.brief_description: A superhero story with a twist! (The twist is it's super generic and lame.)
info.description:
The Power Broker is a business man with a special gift. With a single touch he can bestow on a person a superpower of his choosing, or take it away. Naturally he doesn't do this for free. He always expects payment, either cash up front or the promise of a favour at some time down the line. The Broker is not a man to disappoint - should a client back out of a promise, he has quite a temper and powerful friends capable of bringing even the most gifted individuals to justice.

You visit the Broker for a power, but be careful. The gift you receive may not be quite what you hoped, and you're not the only person in the world who been naturally blessed or received the Broker's boon. Whatever path you take, super powered villains and heroes will stand in your way. Furthermore, the mundane world doesn't exactly take kindly to superhumans running amok, it can't

The Power Broker holds no responsibility for loss of limbs, life or sanity from use of his powers, nor can be held liable for damage caused by improper use or malfunctioning abilities.
